natural problem: Find $g(x)$, with terms in order of decreasing degree, if we have that \[8x^4-7x^2+8x-7+g(x)=x + 1.\]
natural solution: Isolating $g(x),$ we find: \begin{align} g(x) &= (x + 1) - (8x^4-7x^2 + 8x - 7) \\ &= x + 1 - 8x^4 + 7x^2 - 8x + 7 \\ &= \boxed{-8 x^4+7x^2-7x+8}. \end{align}

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. g x + (8 * x powr 4 - 7 * x powr 2 + 8 * x - 7) = x + 1"
shows  "g x = -8 * x powr 4 + 7 * x powr 2 - 7 * x + 8"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

 ### Proof
 Isolating $g(x),$ we find: \begin{align} g(x) &= (x + 1) - (8x^4-7x^2 + 8x - 7) \\ &= x + 1 - 8x^4 + 7x^2 - 8x + 7 \\ &= \boxed{-8 x^4+7x^2-7x+8}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real and g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. g x + (8 * x powr 4 - 7 * x powr 2 + 8 * x - 7) = x + 1"
shows  "g x = -8 * x powr 4 + 7 * x powr 2 - 7 * x + 8"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
